frameDefinitions: Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
An Agent decides temporarily not to perform a Desirable_action or not to interact with a Salient_entity.
This frame has to do with the repetition (and especially the frequency of repetition) of an event.
A Protagonist delays a planned action because they cannot or do not want to proceed until an Expected_event occurs.
The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.
A Protagonist needs a Means action performed for their Benefit.
frameExamples: I have actually <t>held off</t> on buying some movies by WB because of those damned cases.
China will have to face a high <t>frequency</t> of sand storms in the years to come.
The cat <t>waited</t> on top of the washer as Elmer popped the lid off the can of cat food and then pounded the can's contents onto the plate
My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
(1) I <t>rely</t> on you to see that my name is not sullied.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> decides not to engage in a <fen>Desirable_action</fen> for a while or not to interact with a <fen>Salient_entity</fen>.
<fen>Desirable_action</fen> identifies the event or activity in which the <fen>Agent</fen> does not engage for a while.
An entity that evokes a contextually inferrable <fen>Desirable_action</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> is temporarily forgoing.
This role identifies the interval of <fen>Time</fen> during which the the forgoing occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the temporary forgoing occurs.
This role is used for any (bounded) <fen>Event</fen> whose frequency or iteration is described.
The extent to which the actually observed rate of occurrence of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> differs from the expected rate.
The <fen>Interval</fen> is a noun modified by the target word. The target word specifies the frequency of the <fen>Interval</fen> .
The <fen>Time_span</fen> is the length of time of the <fen>Interval</fen>. This role is incorporated by most of the lexical units in this frame.
The number of times per unit of real or scanning time that an <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> is encountered.
An entity which the implicit cognizer encounters with the specified frequency.
The frequency feature of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is under discussion. All the lexical units in this frame incorporate this frame element.
The Time when the Event has a particular frequency.
The sentient being who cannot proceed with their planned activities until a Salient_entity has arrived or an Expected_event has occurred.
A concrete or abstract entity that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> expects to participate in an <fen>Expected_event</fen>, typically that of arriving at the <fen>Place</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Expected_event</fen> is an event that needs to take place or a state that needs to begin to hold before the <fen>Protagonist</fen> can proceed with their planned activities.
The time period during which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
The location in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.
The person or thing whose needs are served by the <fen>Means</fen> action.
An action or state that the <fen>Means</fen> action brings about and from which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> profits.
The person or thing that performs a <fen>Means</fen> action to the <fen>Benefit</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
An object that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> uses to realize a <fen>Benefit</fen>.
An action or state that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> wants to bring about.  It is more or less the <fen>Benefit</fen> viewed in relation to the <fen>Protagonist</fen> rather than the <fen>Means</fen>.
An action performed either by the <fen>Protagonist</fen> or an <fen>Intermediary</fen> that has a <fen>Benefit</fen> for  the <fen>Protagonist</fen> attached to it.
listRoleExamples: Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
Instead, <fex>he</fex> held off on a public announcement of his decision for more than a year.
The board also waited <fex>with the appointment of seven members to the planning and zoning commission</fex> until a policy is set regarding requirements.
I ordered the blackberry cobbler with ice cream for dessert and held off <fex>on another pint</fex> as the rain kept coming down.

Saskatchewan teachers are not a happy lot as they had voted for a strike in June
<fex>then</fex> held off on it to give negotiations a chance during the summer.
The country has been struck by frequent <fex>economic crises</fex>.
The Crested Lark (Galerida cristata) is  <fex>very</fex> frequent from the coastal plain to the mountains.
The meetings occurred at fortnightly <fex>intervals</fex>.
You have to renew the license every <fex>year</fex> .
The state government spends its fiscal year 2006 budget of $23.4 billion at a rate <fex>of $742 per second</fex>.
It costs about US$2.50 to travel 200km (124 mi), but <fex>buses</fex> are infrequent and only one or two buses a day service most routes.
These exposures were likely to be intermittent <fex>in frequency</fex> occurring only when workers were participating in activities at these specific areas.
<fex>He</fex> politely waited, hat in hand, until he could speak.
In busier times several passengers are waiting <fex>for the train</fex>.
She did n't wait <fex>for a reply</fex>, but spelled out the answer herself.
At least 17 ships were waiting <fex>yesterday</fex> to come up the river.
Reporters are waiting <fex>outside the State Guesthouse</fex> for the talks to start .
Everyone loves <fex>compliments</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.
<fex>I</fex> rely on this walking stick to get me around
He still relies on me <fex>to do the head work</fex>
We rely <fex>on you</fex> for feedback and input
I hate having to rely <fex>on my car</fex> to get where I want to go
The user will quickly begin to rely on the pills <fex>to cope with life pressures</fex>.
We rely <fex>on your response</fex>
